testDescription: Test your knowledge with 100 diverse questions
subject: General Knowledge
author: MCQ Generator

questions.question: What is the capital of Australia?
questions.explanation: Canberra is the capital city of Australia, chosen as a compromise between rivals Sydney and Melbourne.

questions.question: Who painted the Mona Lisa?
questions.explanation: Leonardo da Vinci painted the Mona Lisa between 1503 and 1506.

questions.question: What is the chemical symbol for Silver?
questions.explanation: Ag comes from the Latin word 'argentum' meaning silver.

questions.question: Which planet has the most moons?
questions.explanation: Saturn has 146 confirmed moons, the most of any planet in our solar system.

questions.question: What is the largest desert in the world?
questions.explanation: The Antarctic Desert is the largest desert on Earth, covering 14.2 million square kilometers.

questions.question: Who wrote '1984'?
questions.explanation: George Orwell published '1984' in 1949 as a dystopian social science fiction novel.

questions.question: What is the hardest natural substance on Earth?
questions.explanation: Diamond ranks 10 on the Mohs scale, making it the hardest known natural material.

questions.question: Which country gifted the Statue of Liberty to the USA?
questions.explanation: France gifted the Statue of Liberty to the United States in 1886 to commemorate their alliance during the American Revolution.

questions.question: How many bones are in the adult human body?
questions.explanation: Adults have 206 bones, while babies are born with about 300 bones that fuse together as they grow.

questions.question: What is the currency of Japan?
questions.explanation: The Japanese Yen (¥) has been the currency of Japan since 1871.

questions.question: Which organ produces insulin?
questions.explanation: The pancreas produces insulin, which regulates blood sugar levels.

questions.question: Who discovered penicillin?
questions.explanation: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin in 1928, revolutionizing medicine.

questions.question: What is the smallest country in the world?
questions.explanation: Vatican City is the smallest country by both area (0.17 sq mi) and population (about 800).

questions.question: Which gas makes up most of Earth's atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Nitrogen makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

questions.question: Who was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize?
questions.explanation: Marie Curie won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903, shared with Pierre Curie and Henri Becquerel.

questions.question: What is the longest river in the world?
questions.explanation: The Nile River is approximately 6,650 km long, flowing through 11 countries in Africa.

questions.question: In which year did World War II end?
questions.explanation: World War II ended in 1945 with the surrender of Germany in May and Japan in September.

questions.question: What is the square root of 144?
questions.explanation: 12 × 12 = 144, so the square root of 144 is 12.

questions.question: Which element has the atomic number 1?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen has atomic number 1, meaning it has 1 proton in its nucleus.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Pride and Prejudice'?
questions.explanation: Jane Austen published 'Pride and Prejudice' in 1813.

questions.question: What is the speed of light in vacuum?
questions.explanation: The speed of light in vacuum is exactly 299,792,458 m/s, commonly rounded to 300,000 km/s.

questions.question: Which country has the most pyramids?
questions.explanation: Sudan has over 200 pyramids, more than Egypt's 138.

questions.question: What is the main ingredient in guacamole?
questions.explanation: Guacamole is primarily made from mashed avocados mixed with other ingredients.

questions.question: Who developed the theory of relativity?
questions.explanation: Albert Einstein published his Special Theory of Relativity in 1905 and General Theory in 1915.

questions.question: How many continents are there?
questions.explanation: The seven continents are: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America.

questions.question: What is the largest mammal in the world?
questions.explanation: The blue whale is the largest animal ever known to have existed, reaching up to 30 meters in length.

questions.question: Which planet is closest to the Sun?
questions.explanation: Mercury is the smallest and innermost planet in the Solar System.

questions.question: What is the capital of Canada?
questions.explanation: Ottawa was chosen as Canada's capital in 1857 by Queen Victoria.

questions.question: Who painted 'Starry Night'?
questions.explanation: Vincent van Gogh painted 'The Starry Night' in 1889 while in an asylum.

questions.question: What is the chemical formula for water?
questions.explanation: Water consists of two hydrogen atoms bonded to one oxygen atom.

questions.question: Which ocean is the largest?
questions.explanation: The Pacific Ocean covers about 30% of Earth's surface and is the largest.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Hamlet'?
questions.explanation: William Shakespeare wrote 'Hamlet' between 1599 and 1601.

questions.question: What is the tallest mountain in the world?
questions.explanation: Mount Everest stands at 8,848.86 meters above sea level.

questions.question: Which blood type is the universal donor?
questions.explanation: Type O negative blood can be donated to anyone in need.

questions.question: What year did the Titanic sink?
questions.explanation: RMS Titanic sank in the North Atlantic Ocean on April 15, 1912.

questions.question: Which planet is known for its rings?
questions.explanation: Saturn has the most prominent and extensive ring system in our solar system.

questions.question: What is the currency of the United Kingdom?
questions.explanation: The Pound Sterling (£) is the world's oldest currency still in use.

questions.question: Who invented the telephone?
questions.explanation: Alexander Graham Bell patented the first practical telephone in 1876.

questions.question: What is the boiling point of water in Celsius?
questions.explanation: At sea level, pure water boils at 100°C (212°F).

questions.question: Which country is known as the Land of the Rising Sun?
questions.explanation: Japan is called 'Nihon' or 'Nippon' in Japanese, meaning 'origin of the sun'.

questions.question: What is the largest organ in the human body?
questions.explanation: The skin is the body's largest organ, accounting for about 15% of body weight.

questions.question: Which famous scientist developed the laws of motion?
questions.explanation: Isaac Newton formulated the three laws of motion in his 'Principia Mathematica' (1687).

questions.question: What is the capital of Brazil?
questions.explanation: Brasília became Brazil's capital in 1960, replacing Rio de Janeiro.

questions.question: Which language has the most native speakers?
questions.explanation: Mandarin Chinese has about 1.1 billion native speakers.

questions.question: What is the chemical symbol for Potassium?
questions.explanation: K comes from the Neo-Latin 'kalium', which comes from the Arabic 'al-qalyah' meaning 'plant ashes'.

questions.question: Who wrote 'The Odyssey'?
questions.explanation: Homer is traditionally credited as the author of both 'The Iliad' and 'The Odyssey'.

questions.question: What is the smallest prime number?
questions.explanation: 2 is the smallest and only even prime number.

questions.question: Which country hosted the 2016 Summer Olympics?
questions.explanation: Rio de Janeiro, Brazil hosted the 2016 Summer Olympics.

questions.question: What is the study of fossils called?
questions.explanation: Paleontology is the scientific study of life that existed prior to, and sometimes including, the start of the Holocene epoch.

questions.question: Which planet is the hottest?
questions.explanation: Venus has a thick atmosphere of carbon dioxide with dense clouds of sulfuric acid, creating a strong greenhouse effect.

questions.question: What is the capital of Egypt?
questions.explanation: Cairo is Egypt's capital and largest city, located near the Nile Delta.

questions.question: Who discovered gravity?

options.d: Nobody discovered it - it always existed

questions.explanation: Gravity is a natural phenomenon that has always existed. Isaac Newton formulated the law of universal gravitation.

questions.question: What is the freezing point of water in Fahrenheit?
questions.explanation: Water freezes at 32°F and boils at 212°F at sea level.

questions.question: Which animal is known as the 'Ship of the Desert'?
questions.explanation: Camels are called 'Ships of the Desert' because they can travel long distances in desert conditions.

questions.question: What is the capital of Russia?
questions.explanation: Moscow has been Russia's capital since 1918.

questions.question: Which gas do plants absorb during photosynthesis?
questions.explanation: Plants absorb carbon dioxide and release oxygen during photosynthesis.

questions.question: Who painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel?
questions.explanation: Michelangelo painted the Sistine Chapel ceiling between 1508 and 1512.

questions.question: What is the largest bone in the human body?
questions.explanation: The femur, or thigh bone, is the longest and strongest bone in the human body.

questions.question: Which country invented pizza?
questions.explanation: Modern pizza was invented in Naples, Italy in the 18th century.

questions.question: How many players are on a soccer team?
questions.explanation: A standard soccer team has 11 players on the field.

questions.question: What is the capital of Germany?
questions.explanation: Berlin became the capital of reunified Germany in 1990.

questions.question: Which planet has the Great Red Spot?
questions.explanation: Jupiter's Great Red Spot is a giant storm that has been raging for at least 400 years.

questions.question: Who wrote 'The Great Gatsby'?
questions.explanation: F. Scott Fitzgerald published 'The Great Gatsby' in 1925.

questions.question: What is the chemical symbol for Iron?
questions.explanation: Fe comes from the Latin word 'ferrum' meaning iron.

questions.question: Which country has the most islands?
questions.explanation: Sweden has about 267,570 islands, though most are uninhabited.

questions.question: What is the study of birds called?
questions.explanation: Ornithology is the branch of zoology that deals with the study of birds.

questions.question: Which famous composer was deaf?
questions.explanation: Beethoven began losing his hearing in his late 20s and was almost completely deaf by his last years.

questions.question: What is the currency of India?
questions.explanation: The Indian Rupee (₹) has been in use since ancient times.

questions.question: Which is the longest day of the year?
questions.explanation: The Summer Solstice, around June 21st, has the longest period of daylight.

questions.question: Who was the first man to walk on the moon?
questions.explanation: Neil Armstrong became the first person to walk on the Moon on July 20, 1969.

questions.question: What is the capital of France?
questions.explanation: Paris has been the capital of France since the 5th century.

questions.question: Which blood type is the universal recipient?
questions.explanation: Type AB positive can receive blood from any type.

questions.question: What is the main language of Brazil?
questions.explanation: Brazil is the only Portuguese-speaking country in the Americas.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Macbeth'?
questions.explanation: Shakespeare wrote 'Macbeth' around 1606.

questions.question: What is the largest bird in the world?
questions.explanation: The ostrich is the largest and heaviest living bird, reaching up to 2.8 meters tall.

questions.question: Which country has the largest population?
questions.explanation: China has about 1.4 billion people, though India is rapidly catching up.

questions.question: What is the study of the universe called?
questions.explanation: Astronomy is the scientific study of celestial objects and phenomena.

questions.question: Who invented the light bulb?
questions.explanation: Thomas Edison developed the first commercially practical incandescent light bulb in 1879.

questions.question: What is the capital of Spain?
questions.explanation: Madrid has been Spain's capital since 1561.

questions.question: Which gas is used in balloons to make them float?
questions.explanation: Helium is lighter than air and non-flammable, making it safe for balloons.

questions.question: Who painted 'The Last Supper'?
questions.explanation: Leonardo da Vinci painted 'The Last Supper' between 1495 and 1498.

questions.question: What is the capital of Italy?
questions.explanation: Rome has been Italy's capital since 1871.

questions.question: Which animal has the longest lifespan?
questions.explanation: Giant tortoises can live over 150 years, with the oldest recorded at 188 years.

questions.question: What is the chemical symbol for Sodium?
questions.explanation: Na comes from the Latin word 'natrium' meaning sodium.

questions.question: Who wrote 'War and Peace'?
questions.explanation: Leo Tolstoy published 'War and Peace' between 1865 and 1869.

questions.question: What is the largest lake in the world?
questions.explanation: The Caspian Sea, though called a sea, is actually the world's largest lake by surface area.

questions.question: Which planet is known as the Morning Star?
questions.explanation: Venus is often called the Morning Star when it appears in the east before sunrise.

questions.question: What is the capital of China?
questions.explanation: Beijing has been China's capital for most of the last 700 years.

questions.question: Who discovered America?
questions.explanation: Christopher Columbus reached the Americas in 1492 while searching for a route to Asia.

questions.question: What is the chemical formula for table salt?
questions.explanation: Table salt is sodium chloride (NaCl).

questions.question: Which country has the most volcanoes?
questions.explanation: Indonesia has about 130 active volcanoes, more than any other country.

questions.question: Who wrote 'The Divine Comedy'?
questions.explanation: Dante Alighieri wrote 'The Divine Comedy' between 1308 and 1320.

questions.question: What is the fastest land animal?
questions.explanation: Cheetahs can reach speeds of 70-75 mph (112-120 km/h) in short bursts.

questions.question: Which planet is called the Red Planet?
questions.explanation: Mars appears red due to iron oxide (rust) on its surface.

questions.question: What is the capital of South Africa?
questions.explanation: South Africa has three capitals: Pretoria (executive), Cape Town (legislative), and Bloemfontein (judicial).

questions.question: Who discovered X-rays?
questions.explanation: Wilhelm Röntgen discovered X-rays in 1895.

questions.question: What is the smallest unit of life?
questions.explanation: The cell is the smallest unit that can carry out all the processes of life.

questions.question: Which country is both a continent and a country?
questions.explanation: Australia is both a country and a continent.

questions.question: Who wrote 'To Kill a Mockingbird'?
questions.explanation: Harper Lee published 'To Kill a Mockingbird' in 1960.

questions.question: What is the study of earthquakes called?
questions.explanation: Seismology is the scientific study of earthquakes and seismic waves.
